questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents for a routine ultrasound at 28 weeks of gestation. The obstetrician notes an abnormal S/D ratio in the umbilical artery Doppler assessment. Which of the following implications is most likely associated with this finding?

options.label: A
options.text: Low S/D ratio reflects increased resistance in placental blood flow

options.label: B
options.text: Increased resistance to blood flow in the placenta, indicating potential placental insufficiency

options.label: D
options.text: Indicated fetal distress and warrants delivery

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased resistance to blood flow in the placenta, indicating potential placental insufficiency

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presents with infertility and undergoes radiological evaluation. Hysterosalpingography (HSG) reveals a "tobacco pouch" appearance and beaded fallopian tubes. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?
The following sign in breast MRI is characteristic of:

A 17-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe left scrotal pain radiating to the groin. He describes nausea but denies any trauma. On examination, the left testis is high-riding, and there is tenderness upon palpation. Which imaging modality is preferred in this scenario?
Scrotal pain with the whirlpool sign on ultrasound is suggestive of:
questions.explanation:
Finding

Incomplete Torsion

Complete Torsion

Whirlpool Sign

  • A most specific and sensitive sign

Present

Present

Doppler

  • Blood flow is reduced or absent

Reduced

Absent

Elevated Resistive Index (RI)

  • RI > 0.75 indicates compromised blood flow

Elevated (RI > 0.75)

Not applicable

Size Increase

  • Enlargement of the testis and epididymis.

Not typically observed

Present

Echotexture Changes

  • Homogeneous: Early finding (before necrosis)
  • Heterogeneous: Late finding (after 24 hours), suggests necrosis.

Typically homogeneous

Heterogeneous (after 24 hours)

Necrosis Indicators

  • Hypoechoic: represents necrosis.
  • Hyperechoic Regions: represent haemorrhage (if reperfused).

 

Not applicable

Present

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a palpable lump in her right breast that she first noticed two weeks ago. The lump is round, mobile, and non-tender on examination. An ultrasound image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Breast pathology

USG-findings

USG

Simple cyst (Option A)
  • Anechoic with posterior acoustic enhancement
  • Round or ovoid with a smooth hyperechoic wall

Complicated cyst

(Option C ruled out)
  • Internal echoes
  • Fat-fluid level
  • Oil cyst, galactocoel
  • Internal contents move with change in the position of the breast

Complex cyst

(Option B ruled out)
  • Hyperechoic thin septations
  • BI-RADS 3:Probably benign, needs follow-up

Abscess
  • Ill-defined or well-defined outline
  • Maybe anechoic or low-level internal echoes and posterior enhancement

BI-RADS 4/5/6

(Option D ruled out)
  • Hypoechoic mass with irregular wall (spiculated)
  • Taller than wide orientation

Intraductal papilloma
  • Dilated duct
  • Well defined nodule
  • BI-RADS 4A/4B/4C: suspicious for malignancy, biopsy advised

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman undergoes routine mammography screening. The report indicates a 1.5 cm spiculated mass with irregular borders in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. The radiologist assigns it a BIRADS 5 category. Which of the following best describes the implication of a BIRADS 5 category on mammography?
questions.correct_answer: A. Highly suggestive of malignancy, >95% chance

questions.text: Match the following: Disease Mammography features a. Fibroadenoma (i) Eggshell calcification b. Fat Necrosis (ii) Broken-needle appearance c. Duct ectasia (iii) Teacup calcification d. Fibrocystic disease (iv) Popcorn calcifications
questions.explanation:
Condition

Mammographic Findings

Fibroadenoma

Round, well-circumscribed mass with smooth borders; "popcorn" calcifications in older lesions. Benign.

Fat Necrosis

Irregular, spiculated mass with calcifications; central fat density - Eggshell calcification. Often mimics malignancy.

Ductal Carcinoma in Situ (DCIS)

Microcalcifications (Segmental distribution of pleomorphic microcalcifications), often linear or branching, are associated with malignancy.

Invasive Ductal Carcinoma

Irregular, spiculated mass with poorly defined margins. Microcalcifications and architectural distortion.

Fibrocystic disease

Teacup calcification represents the layering out of calcific material in the dependent portion of microcysts on a lateral magnification view.

Duct ectasia

Broken-needle appearance, typical of duct ectasia. Sometimes thicker, more localized calcifications can be seen, giving a ‘lead-pipe’ appearance.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is evaluated for a pelvic mass. An ultrasound shows a complex ovarian mass with a Rokitansky nodule and areas of calcification. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Imaging Modality

Key Features

Ultrasound (US)

Cystic mass with an echogenic nodule (Rokitansky nodule) projecting into the lumen.
Predominantly echogenic mass with posterior sound attenuation (tip of the iceberg sign) due to sebaceous material and hair.
Cystic mass with fine internal echogenic lines (Dot and dash appearance) representing hair.
Fluid-fluid level representing sebaceous material floating on fluid.

Computed Tomography (CT)

Presence of fat and calcifications (e.g., teeth, bones).
 

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)

Sensitive to fat Fat-fluid and fluid-fluid levels, low signal intensity calcifications (e.g., teeth).
Rokitansky nodule/dermoid plug attached to the cyst wall.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pressure. An ultrasound reveals a well-circumscribed, hypoechoic, solid uterine mass with shadowing. What is the most likely imaging diagnosis?

A 42-year-old woman presents with chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and menorrhagia. Transvaginal ultrasound shows an enlarged, asymmetrical uterus with sub-endometrial linear striations, 3-mm cysts, and a "rain shower" appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Grainger and Allison Diagnostic Radiology, Ed.7, page 901, 902
  • ↳ Feeding artery sign (endometrial polyp) | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org

Imaging Modality

Findings in Adenomyosis

Ultrasound (TVUS)
  • Enlarged, globular uterus with asymmetry of the anterior and posterior uterine walls
  • Diffuse echogenic nodules
  • Subendometrial echogenic linear striations (Venetian blind sign)
  • Subendometrial cysts (2-6 mm), seen in 50% of cases
  • Endometrial pseudo widening
  • Poor definition of the endo-myometrial interface
  • Multiple fine areas of attenuation (‘rain shower’ appearance)
  • A speckled pattern of increased vascularity on Color Doppler

MRI (T2-weighted images)

Ill-defined areas of low myometrial signal intensity due to smooth muscle hyperplasia
Diffuse or focal thickening of the junctional zone (JZ)

  • JZ ≥12 mm strongly predicts adenomyosis;
  • JZ ≤8 mm excludes it


High T2 signal intensity foci within low signal myometrium (ectopic endometrial tissue or cystic gland dilatation) (Salt and Pepper appearance)

High T2 signal linear striations (finger-like projections) extending from the endometrium into myometrium

MRI (T1-weighted images)

High T1 signal intensity foci represent small punctate haemorrhages, with a 95% positive predictive value for adenomyosis

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of infertility is undergoing evaluation. The scan image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old woman undergoing controlled ovarian hyperstimulation for in vitro fertilization presents with abdominal pain and significant distension. Which of the following is the most likely finding on an ultrasound seen in this patient that helps differentiate it from PCOS?
Which of the following is not typically associated with IUFD as observed on ultrasound?
questions.explanation:
Step

Description

1. Initial Assessment

Conduct ultrasound to confirm absence of fetal heartbeat and other signs of demise.

2. Follow-Up Imaging

Use MRI for further evaluation if ultrasound is inconclusive or more details are needed.

questions.text: A 12-week pregnant patient presents with a nuchal translucency (NT) measurement of 3.2 mm during her first-trimester ultrasound. What is the most appropriate follow-up ultrasound examination to assess for potential anomalies?

options.label: D
options.text: Doppler ultrasound of the umbilical artery

questions.correct_answer: A. Second-trimester anatomy scan at 20 weeks

questions.text: An ultrasound scan image of a 30-year-old woman who presented for a routine ultrasound at 6 weeks of gestation is shown below. What is the most significant ultrasound finding in this case?
questions.explanation:
Placenta’s membrane status

Timing of cleavage

Diamniotic–Dichorionic

< 72 hours

Diamniotic–Monochorionic

Days 4–7

Monoamniotic–Monochorionic

Days 8–12

Conjoined

Day >13

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman with a history of tubal ligation presents with sudden lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She has a positive serum hCG, and transvaginal ultrasound is shown below. What is the most definitive radiological feature confirming the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy in this case?

A 30-year-old woman with a history of recurrent pregnancy loss presents to the Obstetrics clinic at 4.5 weeks gestation for her ultrasound scanning appointment. An image of the transvaginal ultrasound is shown below. shows a well-defined gestational sac with the double decidual sac sign, but no yolk sac or fetal pole is visible. What is the significance of this ultrasound finding?
questions.correct_answer: C. Indicative of an intrauterine pregnancy
questions.explanation:
Structures visualized

Gestational age (TVS)

Key features

Gestational sac

4.5 to 5 weeks

First sign of pregnancy in an ultrasound

Yolk sac

5 to 6 weeks

First definitive sign of an intrauterine pregnancy.

Fetal heartbeat

5.5 to 6 weeks

M-mode is preferred for the assessment of cardiac activity.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of infertility and recurrent pelvic discomfort is undergoing further evaluation with imaging. She has no history of recent infections but had an episode of acute pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) 5 years ago that was treated with antibiotics. The radiological image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 34-year-old woman is undergoing a fertility evaluation. The transvaginal USG image is shown below. Which phase of the menstrual cycle is she most likely in?
